EXPLANATION OF NAMES OF HERBACEOUS PLANTS.

5.—蘇 Pi (po); 山 蘇 Shan k'in, mountain k'in (now pronounced k'i). The drawing in the Rh ya represents an umbelliferous plant.

Kuo P'o:—The Kuang ya says that Shan k'in is the same as the 當歸 Tang kui, but the latter plant is coarser and larger, it only resembles the k'in.

Hing Ping:—The Shuo wen explains the character k'in by ts'ao, a plant. The mountain k'in, called also 白蘇 Pai k'in (white k'in), is distinguished from the k'in of the plains by its white colour. [See also infra, 49.]

The P., XIV, a. 1, identifies the Pai k'in and the Shan k'in with the Tang kui, an aromatic plant the root of which is much esteemed by the Chinese as a medicine. The rough drawing of the Tang kui in the Ch., XXV, 14, seems to represent an umbelliferous plant.

So moku, V, 5, sub. 當歸 Ligusticum acutilobum, S. et Z., according to Maximowicz; same as Apium ternatum with the same Chinese name in Siebold, Syn. plant. orcon. jap., 246. Herba edulis ac medici usus. This umbelliferous plant is also known from Formosa [Index Flore sin., 332]; probably it occurs also in China proper and may be the Tang kui of the Chinese Pharmacopoeia, which drug Tatarinov in his Catal. med. sin., 19, supposes to be yielded by Levisticum chinense! [See my Early Europ. Res. into the Flora of China, p. 31.]

E., 132, family 當歸.

S., II, 25, two kinds. P., 13 a, 28.

The two drawings in E. are copies from S.

Sm., 20, 133, Aralia edulis and Levisticum.

C., 1250. The Sze chwan Tang kui is the root of an Umbellifer not yet determined; that from the North may be derived from Ligusticum acutilobum, S. & Z.; that imported into Shanghai from Japan is the root of Aralia cordata, Thbg.

6.—樹木 Tuan mu [some editions of the Rh ya write 樹 kia instead of tuan, v. infra 226, 229], 樹根 Kin ch'en, 木根 Mu kin.
Kuo P'o:—Two names for the [common] mu kin. It is a tree resembling the plum. Its flowers expand in the morning and fall off in the evening. They can be eaten. It is also called Ji ki and Wang cheng. Hing Ping quotes the Shi king and Li ki [v. infra, 542].

Mu kin is a common name for Hibiscus syriacus, which is tolerably well represented under the above names in the Rh ya. Tuan is nowadays in Northern China a name applied to the Lime tree, Tilia.

E., 295, family 木槿.

As a synonym of the Shi king. [v. infra, 542.]

P., 36, 64. C., 858. A., XV, 125. All agree.

7.—Shu; Shan ki (mountain thistle).

Kuo P'o:—A thistle which grows in the mountains. [See the next.]

8.—Yang fu; Ki.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the ki (thistle) but is fat (succulent) and larger. It is now called Ma ki (horse's thistle).

Hing Ping [referring to 7 and 8]:—The name of ki (thistle) is applied to a plant growing on the plain. That variety which grows on the mountains is called shu. The Pen ts'ao says one name is Shan ki (mountain thistle), another Shan kiang, another Shan lien. Tao Hung-king [5th century] explains that there are two kinds, the Pai shu, white shu with large hourly, not very fat (fleshy) leaves, and the Chi chi (red) shu, with small leaves, bitter, fleshy. [Comp. infra, 159.]

The shu ts'ao is also mentioned in the Shan hai king. Kuo P'o explains the name by shan ki (mountain thistle).

P., XII, b, 4, shu or pa shu, and fol. 9 ts'ang shu or chi shu, medicinal plants, roots used in medicine. The Ch., VII, 9, sub. shu, figures an Atractylis, a prickly-leaved thistle-like plant of the composite family, and the figures
in the *Rh ya* for 7 and 8 seem to intend the same plant. [See also *Kiu huang*, LI, 8.]

In the *So moku*, XV, 50, 白花 is *Atractylis ovata*, Thbg., and 51 葉花 *A. lancea*, Thbg. But these species, founded upon the form of the leaves, which are very variable in shape, are now reduced to one species. *A. chinensis*, D.C., is also the same plant, which is very common in the Peking mountains. [Comp. HANBURY'S *Science Papers*, p. 255.]

The *P.* considers 7 and 8 of the *Rh ya* to refer to the same plant.

*E.*, 102, family 花.

Figures of eight different kinds,

*S.*, 1, 8, three kinds. *Sm.*, 28.

*C.*, 961, 1167, 1330.

9.—蘭 *Tsien*; 王彗 *Wang sui* (royal besom).

*Kuo P'o:*—Same as 王彗 *wang chou* (royal besom). It resembles the 藤 *li*. Brooms are made of it. In Kiang tung they call it 落帯 *lo chou*. Regarding the *li* plant, *Chenopodium album*, L., *v. infra*, 446.

The *P.*, XVI, 44, identifies the *Wang sui* with the 地蔵 *ti fu* or 擬帯草 *sao chou ts'ao*, or broom plant, which is the *Kochia scoparia*, Schrad., a *Chenopodiacea* common in Northern China and used there for brooms as in Southern Europe.

Under the same Chinese names it is figured in the *Ch.*, XI, 31; in the *Kiu huang*, XLVII, 7, and in the Japanese *So moku*, IV, 41. The drawing in the *Rh ya* referring to 9 may well be intended for *Kochia*.

*E.*, 138, family 地蔵 and 114, family 擬帯子. The figure of the latter is not a Chenopod, but may be a *rubus*, comp. *P.*, 18, 11, and *infra*, 127. *Ti fu*, see *S.*, II, 8; *Sm.*, 128; *C.*, 1263, which all agree.

10.—蘭 *Lu*; 王芻 *Wang ch'u* (royal grass).

*Kuo P'o* explains:—蘭 草 *lu ju*, also called 蝙蝠莎 *Chi kio so* (owl's-foot sedge).
Hing Ping, 某氏, says 菊鹿草 lu lu ju. Shi king quoted. [v. infra, 461.] Drawing in the Rh ya a grass.

E., 107, family 菊. [v. infra, 97, 457]

Shi king, 菊 [v. infra, 73], is given as a synonym.

11.—菊 (also written 菊 Pai), 菊花 Shang tiao.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the li. [v. supra, 9, Chenopodium.]

Hing Ping:—It resembles the li, but the leaves are larger. In 草子 Chuang tsz [philosopher, 4th century, B.C.] the name of a plant li tiao is found. [v. infra, 446.]

The above names in the Rh ya refer probably to a Chenopodium. At Peking 菊花 hui tiao ts'ai is Chenopodium album, L. [Comp. P., XXVII, 28; Ch., IV, 39; Kiu huang, LXIX, 30. See also infra, 446.]

E., 63, family 菊.

Synonym 菊, Shi king. [v. infra, 445.]

12.—菊 Fan; 菊蒿 P'o hao.

Kuo P'o:—Same as 白蒿 pai hao (White Artemisia). [Comp. infra, 433.]

E., 62, 5, family 菊, sub family 白蒿.

Fan is from the Shi king.

H., 108, A. vulgaris, L.

13.—蒿 Hao; 藿 Shen (pronounced also kien).

Kuo P'o:—Now the people call it 青蒿 ts'ing hao. It is fragrant. They employ the plant for cauterizing. It can also be eaten.

Sun Yen (quoted by K'ung Ying-ta) says:—In 荆 King and 楚 Ch'u (pres. Hu kuang) the hao (Artemisin) is called shen. [Comp. infra, 431, Artemisia.]

E., 62, 1, family 菊; sub. family 青蒿.

A., XV, 158, 草蒿 is the same = A. annua, L.

The Japanese drawing Mao Shi, 1, differs.

H., 109, 臭蒿. In North China 香蒿.

14.—薇 Wei; 牡薇 Mou shen (male shen).

Kuo P'o:—It has no seeds.
Hing Ping, referring to 12-14, explains:—Various sorts of hao (Artemisia), variously coloured, with seeds or without seeds. Quotes the Shi king. [Comp. infra, 432.] The figures for 12-14 in the Rh ya may well represent various species of Artemisia.

E., 62, 15, sub. family 牡蒿.
Wei is from the Shi king.
H., 110, A. japonica, Thbg.

15.—薔薵蓬 Ye tiao p'eng; 薔薵蓬 Tsien shu p'eng.

Kuo P'o:—A kind of p'eng.

Hing Ping:—According to the Shuo wen, 蓬 p'eng is a kind of hao (Artemisia). Quotes the Shi king and the Yue ling. [Comp. 436.] The figure in the Rh ya for 15 seems to intend an Artemisia. But the P., XXIII, 15, refers the above names of the Rh ya to Hydropyrum. [v. infra, 350.]

E., 104, family 蓬.
Ye, tiao p'eng, tsien and shu p'eng are four synonyms. The figure represents an Aster.

16.—薔 Pi; 鼠莞 Shu kuan (rat's rush).

Kuo P'o:—This is a kind of kuan (rush, see 98). It has fine fibres like the 龍須 lung su, and is fit for making mats. The best is found in Shu (Sz' ch'uan).

Hing Ping:—The Shuo wen says that the kuan is a grass of which mats can be made.

The drawing in the Rh ya for 16 represents a grass.

[v. infra, 455.]

E., 176, family 石龍芻.
Without figure. Matting grass, the best coming from Sze chuan.

17.—薔 King. [Comp. supra, 8]; 鼠尾 Shu wei (rat's tail).

Kuo P'o:—It furnishes a black dye.

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao says that there are two kinds of this plant, one of them with white, the other with red flowers. It is also called 長翅 ch'ang k'iao. T'ao Hung-
KING reports that this plant grows abundantly in waste places. The people gather it and employ the juice in dyeing. This is the 木蘭 mu lan.

P., XVI, 62, sub. shu wei ts'ao. LI SHI CHEN states that it is also known under the name of 鳥草 wu ts'ao (black plant), for its leaves and flowers are much used for dyeing a black color. Spikes similar to those of the 車前 ch'e ts'ien (Plantago). There are two kinds, with white or red flowers. One author says that the flowers are purple or violet.

The plant figured in the Japanese So moku, I, 29-31, sub. 鼠尾草, is Salvia japonica, Thbg. [See also Kwa wi, 20.] The rough figure under the same Chinese name found in the Kin huang, XLVI, 28, which is reproduced in the Ch., XIV, 12, may well represent a Salvia.

E., 168, family 鼠尾.

The figure may be of Salvia plebeia.

18.—薪薬 Si mi (now pronounced ming); 大薬 Ta tsi (the great tsi).

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the tsi (which is Capsella bursa pastoris, V. infra, 103). It has smaller leaves, and is commonly called 老薬 lao tsi (old tsi).

Hing Ping:—Other names for this plant, given in the Pen ts'ao, are 薬薬 mie si, 太薬 t'ai ts'i, 馬幸 ma sin.

The P., XXVII, 5, says that the si ming, or ta tsi, is nearly allied to the tsi (Capsella bursa pastoris), but larger and not so palatable.

In the Japanese Phon zo, XLVIII, 8-10, the Chinese name 薬薬 is applied to Thlaspi arvense, L. (the Thlaspi majus of Tabernemontanus), also to Lepidium sativum, L. The plant figured under the above name in the Ch., III, 14, is Capsella h. p., whilst Thlaspi arvense, in the Kin huang, LVIII, 8, as well as in the Ch., V, 4, and in the So moku, XII, 3, bears the Chinese name 遇藥葉 ō lan ts'ai. The silicles of the plant are compared by the Chinese authors to
the seed-vessels of the elm. [See also Siebold, Syn. plant. avon. jap., 285.] Capsella b. p. and Thlaspi arvense are common Chinese plants.

E., 60, family 荨 藜 and family 藜.

The name si mi also occurs E., 271, as a synonym of 藜.

19.—藤 T'ü; 虎 枝 Hu chang (tiger's cane). Comp. 150.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 紅 藜 hong ts'ao (Polygonum orientale, L. v. infra, 102), but is coarser and larger and is provided with small prickles. Used for dyeing a red colour.

Hing Ping:—T'ao Hung-king says that according to the Pen ts'ao this plant grows abundantly in waste places. It has the appearance of the 大 馬 藜 ta ma liao (great horse's Polygonum). Spotted stem, round leaves.

In the P., XVI, 83, this plant is described as a Polygonum, the leaves of which resemble those of the apricot. Stem covered with spots, wherefore the plant is also called 斑 枝 pan chang, variegated cane.

Ch., XI, 91; Bad figure. So moku, VII, 78, 虎 枝, Polygonum cuspidatum, S. et Z. In China the above Chinese name seems to be applied to another species of Polygonum.

E., 104, gives 藜 as a synonym of 藜 [v. infra, 24, 150, 209].

E., 164, family 虎 枝 contains three figures of very distinct plants, reproductions of S., IX, 39, but the name 藜 does not appear. None of the figures give an idea of P. cuspidatum, which is also without prickles.

20.—蔓 Meng; 狼 尾 Lang wei (wolf's tail).

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 茅 mao (a grass, Imperata. c. infra, 459). The people use it for thatching roofs.

Comp. infra, 462, Gymnothrix.

E., 106, family 藜. [v. infra, 189].

The character 藜 is taken from the dictionary Yu pien. Most Rh ja editions have 藜, but 藜 ju is preferable, as in E. P., 23, 14. B., 狼 尾 草 Scirpus cyperinus, Kth. The figure in E. is of a graminea.

The figure in Rh ja has the character 狼 for 藜.
21.—瓠果 Hu si; 瓢 Pan.

Kuo P'o explains, 瓢中瓢, which Legge [Shi king] translates "the section of a melon," but it seems rather to mean the pulp of a calabash, or melon. The character pan is thus defined in the Shuo wen.

Hing Ping quotes the Shi king. [v. infra, 384.]

The corresponding drawing in the Rh ya represents a calabash.

E., 47, family 瓢.

For 瓢 the Shi king has 瓢. Not the pulp is meant but the kernels, "Teeth like melon kernels." Calabash is more correct than melon, according to the figure in E. [v. infra, 384].

22.—茹蔔 Ju lu; 茅蔔 Mao shou.

Kuo P'o:—Now it is called 藜 ts'ien and used for dyeing a dark red (緋) colour.

Hing Ping quotes the Shi king. [v. infra, 393.]

The plant 茅 shou, mentioned in the Shan hai king, is, according to Kuo P'o's explanation, the same as mao shou.

According to Li Sun, quoted by K'ung Ying-ta, mao shou is the same as 藜 ts'ien, Rubia cordifolia, L. The Shuo wen says that this plant grows from human blood.

E., 104, family 藜.

The figure is the same as in S., II, 4, and bad.

P., 18 b, 19.

The name ju lu is from the Shi king.

One synonym, mentioned in E., is 地血 Earth-blood.

23.—果蓏之實. The fruit of the kuo lo is called 瓠果 Kua lou. Figured a cucurbitaceous plant with a globular fruit.

Kuo P'o:—Nowadays the people in 齊 Ts'i (Northern Shan tung) call it 天瓜 t'ien kua (heavenly gourd).

Hing Ping observes that according to Li Sun's explanation kuo lo means properly not the whole fruit, but the seed only. The Pen ts'ao king states that the leaves of this plant
resemble those of the kua (gourd or melon); they are of a dark green colour. It is a trailing plant, and flowers in the 6th month; in the 7th month it produces a gourd-like fruit.

This is a Trichosanthes. [v. infra, 385.]

E., 151, family 桂樹 (see 310, family 無患子, Sm. 43, 221, Bryony, Trichosanthes).

Kuo lo is from the Shi king.

Among the synonyms is 黃瓜, but the figure is of a gourd, not of Cucumis sativus, L.

E., 170, family 白藥子. A., XV., 153, Trichosanthes palmata, Roxb., also called 天花粉. Comp. Sm., 222.

24.—茶 T'iu; 苦菜 K'u ts'ai (bitter vegetable).

Kuo P'o quotes the Shi king [v. infra, 365] and says that the k'u ts'ai is used for food.

Hing Ping:—In the Pen ts'ao it is also called 遊山 and 游冬 yu tung. Its leaves resemble those of the 苦苣 k'u kü (Lactuca) but are smaller; if broken they exude a milky juice. Yellow flowers, resembling those of the ku or Aster. The plant is edible, but it has a bitter taste.

This is a Sonchus or a Lactuca [v. infra, 365], which accords with the drawing given in the Rh ya.

E., 59, family 茶, the figure=S., X, 38, Lactuca denticulata, Max.

茶, 苦 and 苣 occur in the Shi king and are synonyms; k'u ts'ai v. Li ki. K'u kü is also a synonym of later date.

Another synonym is 苦苣 v. S., X, 38. Sm. 62. Cichorium. * A., XV., 160, Cichorium Endivia, L.

H., 189, Lactuca squarrosa, Miq.

Lactuca amurensis, Reg., and sometimes at Ichang Taraxacum officinale, Wg.

P., XXVII., 14.

In Japan k'u ts'ai is determined as Sonchus oleraceus, L.

山苦苣 as Lactuca Raddeana, Max.

萵苣 as Lactuca sativa, L.

山萵苣 as Lactuca squarrosa, Miq.
K'yu ts'ai is given as a synonym in E., 129, family 貝母 [v. infra, 75] also E., 161, family 菊科 [v. infra, 144] and E., 164, family 龍葵 [v. infra, 79, 182].

T'yu is quoted from the Shi king as a synonym in E., 103, family 茶 [v. infra, 48, 188 and supra, 20], and E., 104, family 藤, from the Chou li [v. supra, 19, infra, 150, 209].

25.—崔 Kia (perhaps ch'ui); 種 Lei (t'ui or chui, W.D. 926).

Kuo P'o:—This plant is now called 菊科 ch'ung wei. Its leaves resemble those of the 花 jen (Perilla). Square stem. White flowers arranged on the joints (in whorls). Another name is 益母 i mu, according to the Kuang ya.

Hing Ping:—Li Sun calls this plant 臭穢草 ch'ou wei ts'ao (stinking weed). Mentioned in the Shi king. [v. infra, 444.]

The plant in question is Leonurus sibiricus, L., which, however, has red, not white flowers as Kuo P'o suggests. The drawing in the Rh ya agrees.

E., 129, family 益母; the figure is not of Leonurus sibiricus, but may be of L. macranthus, Max., which has the same Chinese name in Manchuria.

P., 15, 24. Sm., 132. C., 550. Pr., 231. Kia, v. Shi king.

Lycopus lucidus, Turcz, is also called I mu in Manchuria, this has white flowers, and occurs also in the Central and Northern Provinces of China.

26.—蘭 Ni (read also i); 種 Shou.

Kuo P'o:—A small herb, variegated like a ribbon (縷).

Hing Ping quotes the Shi king. [v. infra, 454, Ribbon grass, Phalaris?]. The figure in the Rh ya does not agree.

W.D., 1098. E. not found.

27.—粢 Tsz'; 種 Tsi.

Kuo P'o:—The people in Kiang tung now apply the term tsz' to the 米 su. (Su, it seems, is here to be understood as a general name for corn, v. infra, 343, 347).
Hing Ping quotes the Tso chuan and the Li ki. [v. infra, 343, Panicum miliaceum, L.]

The corresponding figure in the Rh ya seems to represent Setaria.

E., 29, family 稗, the figure represents a Panicum; 糠子 is its popular name.

28.—衆 Chung; 糠 Shu.

Kuo P'o:—Same as the 粘粟 (glutinous su or Setaria italica).

Hing Ping quotes the Shuo wen, where it is stated that the shu is a glutinous form of the tsi (Panicum miliaceum). The people in Northern China use it to ferment liquors. The figure in the Rh ya seems to refer to Setaria. [v. infra, 348.]

E., 25, family 稗, the figure, if intended for rice, is bad.

Shu is mentioned as a synonym.

E., 31, family 稗, figure a Panicum, possibly P. italicum.

Chung is placed below shu.

In Japan six Panicum bear Chinese names: P. frumentaceum, Roxb. 稗; P. italicum, L. 條; P. Germanicum, Trin. 栗; P. miliaceum, L. 稗; P. sanguinale, L. 馬唐; P. viride, L. 狗尾草.

29.—戎叔 Jung shu is the same as 荏菽 Jen shu.

Kuo P'o:—This is the plant called 胡豆 Hu tou (foreign bean).

Hing Ping:—Fan Kuang as well as She Jen and Li Sun all explain the above names of the Rh ya by hu tou. But they were mistaken. As jung is likewise a term for foreigners [western barbarians] they concluded that jung shu and hu tou are the same. Cheng Huan and Sun Yen identified the jung shu correctly with the 大豆 ta tou or great bean. [Comp. infra, 355, Shi king.]

The ta tou is the Soja hispida, Moench, or soy bean. The hu tou, or foreign bean, is the Faba sativa, or common bean, one of the cultivated plants introduced from Western Asia.
into China, in the second century B.C., by the famous general Chang K'ien.

Figure of the jung shu in the Rh ya a leguminous plant.

E., 36, 12, family 豆.

Both Jung shu and Hu tou are given as synonyms of 豆豆. W.D., 1038, says, "probably the lablab?" The figure points to a Vicia. Sm., 172, Pisum arvense.

E., 35, 12, family 豆, speaks of 大豆, the figure if meant for Soja hispida, Moench, [now Glycine hispida, Max.] is disfigured. 白豆, of Parker, 46, is distinguished in E., 36, 11, as a synonym of 飯豆, comp. P., 24, 1, and 24, 17. Sm., 88.

In Japan Hu tou is Indigofera decora, Ldl.; Wan tou, Pisum sativum, L.; Ta tou, Glycine hispida, Max.

30.—卉 Hui; 草 Ts'ao.

Kuo P'o says it is a general name for herbaceous plants.

Hing Ping:—The term 百卉 po hui occurs in the Shi king. [v. infra, 402.]

31.—雀麦 Tsio mai (bird wheat).

Kuo P'o:—Same as 燕麦 Yen mai (swallow wheat).

Hing Ping:—According to the Pen ts'ao it grows in waste places and forests. The plant resembles wheat but is more slender. The grain resembles the 穗麦 kung mai (naked barley) but is smaller.

P., XXII, 26. Figured Ch., I, 31. Kiu huang, LII, 1. Phon zo, XL, 10, 11 sub. 雀麦 represents various gramineous plants.

E., 32, 20, 21, family 麦.

The figures given of Tsio mai and of Yen mai are distinct species. Jap., 380, determines the first as Bromus japonicus, Thbg., and the other, 371, as Brachypodium sylvaticum, Roem. & Schult.

Sm., 157, Oat.; differs from the figures, but I received this name for Avena sativa, L., from Ningpo.
33.—壇鳥落葉；兒落葉；兒落葉。 All unknown to the Chinese commentators.

34.—薑 Yen 薑瓜 T'u kua.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 土瓜 t'u kua (earth gourd).

Hing Ping:—The leaves and the fruit resemble those of the t'u kua, which is the same as the 王瓜 wang kua (royal gourd) mentioned in the Yue ling. [v. infra, 386, Thladiantha dubia, Bge.]

Some of the ancient authors quoted identify the yen with the plant mentioned Rh ya, 152, q.v.

35.—菊頭 Lie chen; 菊首 Shi shou (pig's head).

Kuo P'o:—In the Pen ts'ao this plant is also called 菊頭 chi lu (pig's head) and 蟲蘭 shan chu lan. In Kiang tung it is now commonly called shi shou and employed in boiling the pupa of the silkworm [to kill it].

Hing Ping:—A medicinal plant. In the Pen ts'ao it has, besides the names already mentioned, the following names: 天名精 tien ming tsing, 麥句薑 mai ku kiang, 蝦薑薑 hia ma lan, 王門精 wang men tsing. According to the Pie lu, it is fragrant and known also under the name of 天薑精 tien man tsing. The southern people call it 地蔥 ti sung (earth cabbage). Its taste is sweet and bitter. It resembles the 藍 lan (indigo plant).

In the P., XV, 68, this plant is noticed under the name of 天名精 tien ming tsing with the above synonyms. It is said to have small, fragrant, yellow flowers resembling the ku flowers (Aster, Chrysanthemum).

In the So moku, XV, 62, under the name of 天名精, is a drawing of Carpesium abrotanoides, L., (Compositae), which agrees well with the figure given under the same Chinese name in the Ch., XI, 16.
E., 174, family 天名精. The figure apparently from S., II, 2, not good. Sm., 12, Amaranthus tristis is doubtful. Carpesium abrotanoides, L., can also not be accepted exclusively, for among the 23 synonyms we find 種穀, S., IV, 34, P., XV, 72, which is Siegesbeckia orientalis, L. according to B., C. 395, A., XV, 70 and Jap., 2078. [Comp. E., 167.]

36.—荊 P'ing; 馬蔘 Ma chou (horse's besom).

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 著 shi (Ptarmica sibirica), and is fit for besoms.

Hing Ping says that the plant is commonly called 荊荊 shi p'ing. The P., XV, 57, refers the above names to an Iris. [v. infra, 467.]

E., 138, family 地蔘.

This is a synonym of 荊 [supra, 9].

37.—薺; 懷羊. Unknown to the Chinese commentators.

38.—薺 Kiao 牛蔘 niu k'in (k'i).

Hing Ping:—A vegetable. Seeds used in medicine. The Pen ts'ao says that this plant grows in marshes. It resembles the 鬼針 kui chen ("devil's needle," Bidens) and also the 菜菜 tien ts'ai (Beta). Flowers of a light green colour, seeds dark yellow, resembling those of the 防風子 fang feng tsz (Stenocelium, Umbellifera).

39.—薺 tu 蔬 lo (lu) fei (pei).

Kuo P'o:—The character 蔬 stands for 蔬 fu. The lo fei or lo fu is akin to the 燕菁 wu tsing (Rape), but has violet flowers and a great (long) root. Its common name is 薤薺 po tu.
Hing Ping.—Sun Yen calls it 紫花菘 tsz' hua sung (cabbage with violet flowers). Another name is 温菘 wen sung. Large root. Now its common name is 蘿蔔 lo p'o.

In the Fang yen the same plant is compared to the 芥 kiai (mustard plant) from which it is distinguished by its violet flowers. In Eastern 鲁 Lu (Shan tung) it is also known by the name of 菜遠 la t'u. The commentary adds that its seeds are as large as small beans.

The plant here spoken of is the Radish, Raphanus sativus, L. It has violet flowers and large seeds; its common name is nowadays 蘿蔔 lo p'o, which appears first in Chinese books in the 9th century. In the Kuang yun Dictionary, which was compiled in that period, it is stated that this name was in use in the State of 秦 Ts'in (Shen si, Eastern Kan su). In the T'ung Pen ts'ao, published two centuries earlier, we first meet with another name for the radish, 菜服 lai fu. Under this name it is described by Li Shih-chen in the P., XXVI, 41, and figured Ch., IV, 15.

In Kæmpfer's Amoen. exot., 823, Japanese plants, we read 菜服 Rai fuku, vulgo "Daikon," Raphanus major orbicularis vel radice permagna oblonga. With the same Chinese name the radish is figured in the So moku, XII, 27, 28.

As the radish is mentioned in the Rh ya it may be assumed that it has been cultivated in China from remote antiquity. From China its cultivation spread over the neighbouring countries, where the people generally adopted also the Chinese name of the plant. The Anamese and Malay call it lobac. (See Loureiro's Flora cochin., 481; Watson's Native and Scient. Names of Eastern Asiat. Plants.) In Tibetan it is la phug (Jeschke, Tibet. Dictionary); in Mongol and Kalmyk lao pang, lo bin, but also turma. The latter name is, it seems, derived from the Persian appellation turup, used to designate the radish.
E., 70, family 萝蔔, four different plants are figured, among them Raphanus sativus, a Crucifera and Daucus carota, an Umbellifera. The third plate is doubtful. H., 251, says that Shan lo po is a common name for Phytolacca acinosa, Rox. The figure, showing a turnip-like root and large digitate leaves, must be intended for something else. There are 20 synonyms enumerated.

41.—茵 Siu; 芝 Chi.

Kuo P'o:—The chi flowers three times in one year. It is a felicitous plant.

Hing Ping:—The Lun heng [first century] says that the chi grows in the ground and absorbs the vapours of the earth. It is therefore considered a felicitous plant. The 禮 Li says, "when the ruler is charitable, then the chi grows."

I have not been able to find Hing Ping's quotation in the Li classics, but a similar sentence is found in the Shui ying t'ü ki [6th century] quoted in the K.D. The Shuo wen defines 芝 by 神草, "divine herb." Williams, in his Dictionary, 811, makes siu chi to be one name, designating a gynandrous plant. The text of the Rh ya, however, gives siu as a synonym of chi, regarding which Williams, 53, correctly states that it is a Fungus. The corresponding figure in the Rh ya seems to represent a branching Fungus, the 露芝 ling chi, or felicitous chi, which is sold in the Peking apothecary shops. It is orange colonred, of a ligneous structure and branched. The ling chi has been figured and described by Father Cibot under the name of Agaric ramifié, in the Mémoires conc. les Chinois, IV, p. 500. [See also Grosier, la Chine, III, 256.]

The P., XXVIII, 35, identifies the ling chi with the 石耳 shi rh (stone mushroom) but gives no details about it.

55.—藏 Chen; 寒浆 Han tsiang (cooling juice).

Kuo Po:—This plant is now called 酸浆草 suan tsiang ts'ao (acid juice). In Kiang tung they call it 苦蔵 k'u chen (bitter chen).

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao terms it 醋浆 ts'iu tsiang (vinegar juice) T'ao Hung-king states that it is a common plant near dwelling-places. The leaves are eaten. The fruit is a capsule (bladder) within which is a berry of a yellowish red colour, resembling a plum.

This agrees well with the fruit of the winter cherry, Physalis Alkekengi, L., a common plant in Northern China, called also teng lung ts'ao (lantern plant) and hung ku niang (red girl). This plant is well figured under the above Chinese name suan tsiang in the Ch., XI, 48, and in the So moku, III, 43.

56.—藤花 Kie kou (hou). 英花 Kue kuang.

Kuo P'o:—This is the 英明 Kue ming. Leaves pointed, yellow; red flowers. The fruit resembles that of the 山茱萸 Shan chu yu (Cornus). It is also called 藤 Ling. In Kuan si (present Shen si) it has the above name Kie kou.

Hing Ping:—T'ao Hung-king, in explaining the Pen ts'ao, states that the plant in question has leaves resembling those of the 茶豆 Kiang tou (Cassia?). The seeds resemble a horse's hoof, whence the name 马蹄英明 Ma ti kue ming. The Shuo wen calls it 藤 Ling, the Kuang ya 羊蹄花 Yang chi chu. In 楚 Chu (Hu kuang) they call it 菜 K'i, in 秦 Ts'in it is called Kie kou.

P., XVI, 41, Kue ming. Li Shi-chen states that there are two kinds of Kue ming, one of them is called Ma ti kue ming (horse's hoof Kue ming). Its stem is 3 or 4 feet high, the leaves (leaflets) are larger than those of the mu su (*Medicago sativa*); they are narrow at the base and enlarge towards the summit. In daytime they are open, at night they all fold together, two and two. In autumn the flowers, with five petals of a pale yellow, appear. They are followed by long pods resembling those of the 豆豆 Kiang tou (*Dolichos sinensis*). They contain many dark green seeds resembling a horse's hoof. The other kind is called 藤芒 英明 Kiang mang kue ming. It resembles the former, but the leaves are pointed, resemble those of *Sophora japonica* and do not fold together at night. Dark yellow flowers, small pods like a little finger, small seeds resembling those of *Hibiscus abelmoschus*.

The name of the last-described is more commonly written 望江南 Wang kiang nan. Kiu huang, LIII, 22, and Ch., XI, 30. The plant figured there is a Cassia. At
Peking Wang kiang nan is the Cassia Sophera, L. The plants described by Li Shi-chen under the above names are without doubt two species of Cassia, but what Kuo P'o states regarding the Kue ming does not agree.

In the So moku, VIII, 2, 江南 is Cassia Tora, L., and 3, 江南 Cassia occidentalis, L.

The other figure cannot be meant for a leguminosa.

E., 179, family 江南 cannot be the same, its synonym is

Datura alba, N. & E., by Pr.; C., 894, (302); as Datura Metel, L., by A., XV, 164; as Hyoscyamus niger, by Sm., 29, 115, (also Andromeda, 84). The figure is neither one nor the other, nor can it mean a leguminosa. As 黄杜鵑 yellow Azalea is among the synonyms, it may mean Rhododendron chinense.

64.—蘇 *Su*; 桂荳 *Kui jen*.

*Kuo P'o*:-The *Su* is a sort of *Jen* (oleiferous plant).

*Hing Ping*:-T'AO HUNG-KING, in explaining the *Pen ts'ao*, says, the leaves of this plant are of a purple colour underneath and very fragrant. There is a variety of it with the leaves not purple-coloured and not fragrant. There is also a wild species growing in marshes and called 水蘇 *Shui su* (water *su*) or 雞蘇 *Ki su* (cock's *su*).

*P.*, XIVb, 94, 蘇 *Su*. LI SHI-CHEN distinguishes two sorts of *Su*. One of them, called 紫蘇 *Ts' su* (purple *su*) has a square stem; roundish-pointed, toothed leaves, purple on both sides when the plant grows in rich soil, purple only underneath when it grows in poor soil. It is very fragrant. Young leaves eaten as a vegetable, also pickled with plums. They are also used to prepare a beverage. The other kind, with its leaves white on both sides, not
fragrant, is called 白蘇 Pai su (white su) or 蔥 Jen. An oil is expressed from its seeds. [But it seems the Tsz' su also produces an oil].

Two distinct labiate plants are figured under the above names in the Ch., XXV, 25, the Jen or Pai su, the oil yielding, and 27, 29, the Su or Tsz' su or purple coloured.

Amaen. exot., 911, 茴 dsin, vulgo je et fakkuso. Ocimo majori affinis; ex cujus semine Japones celebre oleum jeno abra conficiunt.

Ibidem 蘿 sso, usitate naraje et sjuko gusa. An Ocimum majus, Matth. et Tabern.?

So moku, XI, 26, 茴 Perilla ocimoides, L. Siebold, Icon. plant. jap. inedit, VI, same identification. Siebold, Syn. plant. acon., 190. Acynos yegoma 茴 E seminibus exprimitur oleum, quo celebreta japonica pluvialia sunt obdueta.

Phon zo, XII, 12, 13, 茴 and So moku, XI, 25, 紫蘇 Perilla arguta, Bth. Siebold, Plant. japon. acon., 189. Acynos siso, 紫蘇 Ocimum crispum, Thbg., variat foliis purpurascentibus.

Thus in Japan the latter Chinese name, Tsz' su (purple su) is applied both to Perilla arguta and Ocimum crispum. I may observe that Thunberg is wrong in identifying [Flora jap., 248] his O. crispum with Kämpfer's siso or murasaki [Amaen. exot., 784], for this latter is Lithospermum erythrorhizon, S. & Z. [Comp. infra, 142].

According to Loureiro, Flora cochin., 446, the Tsu su (Tsz' su) in Southern China, is Melissa cretica, L. He says: "tota planta rubrofusca, mixto odore Pulegii, et eimicum imbuta. Foliis recentibus vescuntur indigenae in acetariis." This is probably not Melissa cretica. Loureiro's Dendidia nankinensis, sin. kiain nan tsu su (Tsz' su of Kiang nan), l.c., 448, odore et colore Melissae creticæ, is, according to Bentham, Flora hongk., 276, Perilla ocimoides, var. crispa.
The labiate plant, cultivated at Peking under the name of Su (vulgo su tsz') for the oil expressed from its seeds, is Perilla ocimoides. This plant has an unpleasant, powerful smell.

According to Henry, Chinese Names of Plants, 395 and 512, P. ocimoides is much cultivated for its oil in Hu pei, and is called there Su ma (su hemp). A variety with red flowers is Tsz' su.

The 水蘇 Shui su, mentioned by a commentator on the Rh ya, is likewise a Labiate, but I am not prepared to say to what genus it belongs. See P., XIVb, 97. Ch., XXV, 14. Phon zo, XII, 14.

The first figure, 紫蘇, is Perilla ocimoides, L., in Jap., 1588, P. arguta, Bth. The figure for 水蘇, if meant for a Labiate, is not a success; it may be a Scrophularinea or an Acanthacea. The figure of 菖 may indicate another Perilla. In Jap., 1589, P. ocimoides.

67.—蔘 Men; 赤苗 Chi miao (red blade).

Kuo P'o:—It is nowadays called 赤梁果 Chi liang su (red *Setaria italica*).

Hing Ping:—The above character men is the same as 蔘 in the Shi king. [v. infra, 345, *Setaria italica*.]

E., 30, family 蔘, both the red and white (68) varieties are *Panicum miliaceum*. [v. infra, 341-343.]

68.—苞 K'i; 白苗 Pai miao (white blade).

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 白梁果 Pai liang su (white *Setaria italica*).

V. infra, 346, *Setaria italica*.

E., 59, family 茶, *Lactuca*: k'i is a synonym.

E., 137, family 地黃, as a synonym = *Rehmannia*.

E., 42, family 慈蔘 as a synonym = *Coix lacryma*.

69.—秬 Ka; 黑黍 Hei shu (black millet).

Kuo P'o quotes the Shi king.

Hing Ping:—This is the great black millet used for making the sacrificial spirit 酒酒.

V. infra, 342, *Panicum miliaceum*.

70.—穀 Fou (p'ei). 一穀二米 (two seeds within one glume).

Kuo P'o:—This is a kind of hei shu or black millet distinguished from the foregoing (by having two seeds in one glume). In the reign of the Han Emperor Ho ti (A.D. 89-106), in the district of 任城 Jen ch'eng (now Yen chou fu, in Shan tung), such a black double-kernelled millet was reaped; more than 3 hu of it were gathered.
Hing Ping.—This double-kernelled millet was used in olden time for making the spirits offered in the ancestral worship of princes, it being regarded as an unusual thing.

V. infra, 342.

71.—稲 T'ü; 稻 Tao.

Kuo P'o.—Nowadays in 沛國 P'eı kuo (northern part of present An hui Province) the people use the term 稲 (to designate Rice).

Hing Ping quotes the Shi king, Li ki, Shuo wen and the Tsz lin [3rd century]. The latter states 稗 No is the name for the 粘稻 Nien tao (glutinous rice) and 稻 Keng is the [common] rice without the glutinous quality. In the Pen ts'ao these two kinds are called 糯米 keng mi and 稻米 tao mi.

The Rh ya makes t'ü and tao to be the same thing, as does also the Shuo wen. But tao is nowadays a general term for rice, whilst t'ü, according to the dictionary Tsi yün [11th century] is the same as no or glutinous rice. [v. infra, 337, 338, about Rice mentioned in the Classics.] The terms tao and t'ü occur also in the Shan hai king, 稻米 tao mi and 種米 t'ü mi, used for the sacrifices offered to the mountain spirits.

E., 25, family 稻.

P., 22, 29. Sm., 185.

72.—薔 Fu; 薔薔 K'iung mao. [Comp. also 51.]

Kuo P'o.—That with red flowers is called k'iung; another kind with yellow or white flowers is called 蓬薔 Ling t'iao.

The name ling t'iao is not found in Chinese botanical works. The character ling is a name for the water ealtrop, Trapa, and this plant is represented in the corresponding figure of the Rh ya. This identification is no doubt erroneous. K'iung mao is a magic herb mentioned in the Li sao. [v. infra, 416.]

See note to 51. Calystegia heteracea.
73.—臺 T'ai; 夫須 Fu su (poor man's need).

Kuo P'o:—Ch'eng Huan, in commenting upon the Shi king, says that this plant (a sedge) can be made into rain-cloaks and hats.

V. infra, 457, Scirpus.

E., 107, family 莎 Cyperus. [v. infra, 97].

74.—薔薇. Unknown to the Chinese commentators.

75.—菌 Meng; 貝母 Pei mu (mother-of-cowry shell).

Kuo P'o:—The roots are round like small cowry shells and white. The leaves and flowers resemble those of the 韭 Kiu (Allium odorum).

Hing Ping:—This is a medicinal plant. In the Shi king its name is written 菌 Meng. The Pen ts'ao calls it 空草 Kung ts'ao. T'ao Hung-king states that it grows by waysides. The root looks like cowries, whence the name.

V. infra, 423, Fritillaria.

E., 129, family 貝母, the three figures are copies from S., II, 28, none of them resembling Fritillaria.

76.—蔽 K'iao; 蝴蝶 Pi jou.

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 荨薺 King k'ui, for it resembles the k'ui (Althaea, Malva). Violet flowers. 謝氏 says that it is a small plant with not many leaves but an abundance of flowers.

V. infra, 369, Malva.

E., 85, family 荨薺 with 39 names. Of 7 figures, only 3 belong to Malvaceae.

Hi and fu k'ui [v. infra, 115] are synonyms, also kien and jung k'ui [v. infra, 136], and Chung k'ui and fan lu [v. infra, 148, 368].

77.—艾 Ai; 冰臺 Ping t'ai.

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 艾蒿 Ai hao.

This is Artemisia vulgaris, L. [v. infra, 429.]
78.—薺 Tien; 薺歷 Ting li.

Kuo Po:—Leaves and fruit resemble those of the 芥 Kie (Mustard). Another name is 狗薺 Kou tsi.

Hing Ping:—The Kuang ya calls it kou tsi. In the Pen ts'ao there are the names 丁歷 Ting li; 太室 T'ai shi; 大適 Ta ti. T'ao Hung-king says, the plant is found by waysides. Seeds small, yellow, bitter.

P., XVI, 51, and Ch., XI, 63, describe and figure under ting li, a cruciferous plant. Tatarinov, Catal. med. sin., 56, Ting li, Semina Sisymbrii. Four species of Sisymbrium, including our common S. Sophia, are known from Northern China [See Index Flora sin., I, 45]. Loureiro, Fl. cochin., 479, gives Ting li as the Chinese name for Lepidium petraeum, but according to the Index Flora sin., 41, Loureiro's plant is Nasturtium palustre, D.C.

In Japan the above Chinese name, Ting li, is applied to several cruciferous plants. Phon zo, XIX, 2, 荠薺 Nasturtium palustre, D.C., also Arabis perfoliata, Lam. In Hoffm. & Sch., 219, same Chinese name, Draba nemoralis, L. So moku, XII, 4, the same plant 苦亭歷 (bitter ting li).

E., 141, family 荠薺, with three figures of Crucifera.

摩草 of the Li ki is also referred to this. Jap., 825, Draba nem.

79.—符 Fu; 鬼目 Kui mu (devil's eye).

Kuo Po:—There is now in Kiang tung a plant kui mu. Its stem resembles that of the 葛 Ko (Pachyrhizus); its leaves are orbicular and covered with hairs, the fruit is shaped like an ear-ring. It is of a reddish colour. The plant grows in a bushy manner.

The P., XVIII, b, 31, identifies the kui mu of the Rh ya with the 白英 Pai ying, a climbing plant with 5 lobed tomentose leaves; fruit globular, resembling that of the 龍葵 Lung k'ui (Solanum nigrum), but of a dark red colour. The figure of the pai ying in Ch., XXII, 18, represents a Solanum with lobed leaves.
So moku, III, 52, 白英 Solanum dulcamara, L.

E., 158, family 白英. The figure indicates a twiner, different from the figure in Rh ya. Jap., 2100, S. dul.

Fu is also synonym of 荷 or Limnanthemum, E., 66.

80.—蘇；庚草. Unknown to the Chinese commentators.

81.—殼 Ao; 蘇蘿 Sao lu.

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 紫蘇 Fun lu, also 雞腸草 Ki ch'ang ts'ao (chicken bowels herb).

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao says, the fun lu is of a bitter taste. T'ao Hung-king states that the people use it as a vegetable for soup.

P., XXVII, 6, fan lu, a creeping plant. The drawing in Ch., IV, 7, s.n., agrees with the figure; So moku, VIII, 65, under 紫蘇, which is Stellaria neglecta, Weihe. But the plant 雞腸草, is kept apart in P., XXVII, 7, in Ch., IV, 8, and in the Japanese botanical works. In the So moku it is Eritrichium pedunculare, A.D.C.

E., 144, family 紫蘇, the figure may be of a Stellaria.

82.—離南 Li nan; 活荳 Huo t'o. [Comp. also 143.]

In the Shan hai king this plant is repeatedly mentioned under the name of 冠脫 K'ou t'o. Kuo P'o explains that it is an herbaceous plant of the southern provinces, which grows to the height of more than ten feet, and has large leaves resembling those of the 荷 Ho (Lotus flower). The pith of the stem is very white. The people of 雲 Ling and 桂 Kui [Hu nan] cultivate it. It is called 灌 Kuan, and grows like a tree.

In P., XVIIIb, 28, the above names, found in the Rh ya and Shan hai king, are referred to the 通脫木 T'ung t'o mu. Li Shu-ch'en explains this name, saying that the pith is obtained by stripping off the rind. T'ung—to go through; t'o—to peel off. Ch'en Ts'ang-k'i [first half of the 8th century] states that the t'ung t'o tree grows on the
sides of the mountains. The leaves resemble those of the 麻 Pi ma (Ricinus communis). The stem contains a beautiful light, white pith, which is used by women for making fancy articles. Its common name is 通草 Ts'ung ts'ao. Under this latter name Ch., VIII, 64, gives a good drawing of the Aralia (Fatsia) papyrifera, (Hooker) the pith of which, as is now well known, yields the so-called "rice-paper." This plant was long known as growing plentifully in Formosa. [Comp. Kew Journ. Bot., IV (1852), p. 53 tt. 1, 2.] Recently Dr. A. Henry discovered it also in Hu pei [Chinese Names of Plants, 488, ts'ung ts'ao; Ind. Florae sin., 341]. E. H. Parker [China Rec., IX, 327] reports that the rice-paper plant, ts'ung ts'ao, is produced in Sung k'uan (Sz' ch'unan, near the Kneichou frontier). The pith paper in China is chiefly used for manufacturing artificial flowers for women's hair. Besides this, the Chinese painters execute brilliant paintings on it. Aralia papyrifera is an herbaceous plant, but it has sometimes a tree-like appearance.

通草 Akelia quinata, Deen., and 通脱木 Fatsia horrida, (Smith), are found in Japan. [See Phon zo, XXX, 8, 9, and 10, 11.]

E., 134, family 藤属, with two figures, one for Fatsia papyrifera, the other a branched prickly plant.

The names given, infra 143, are included here.

E., 111, family 藤属 [v. supra, 51] mentions li nan of the Rh ya as a synonym of Calystegia.

83.—龍天蔘; 紅蔘根. Unknown to the Chinese commentators. [Comp. infra, 105 and 361.]

84.—薄 P'ang; 龍蔘 Yin jen.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 蔬 Su (Perilla). The plant is covered with hairs. In Kiang tung it is now called yin jen. The people gather and pickle it; they boil it also for food.
This plant is not noticed in the Pen ts'ao kang mu.

E., 143, family 青蔥 [v. supra, 45], yin jen occurs as a synonym.

85.—菌 Yu; 蔓于 Man yu.

Kuo P'o:—This is a water-plant, also called 荷于 Hien yu. In Kiang tung they call it yu.

P., XVI, 85, and Ch., XIV, 33, consider the yu plant of the Rh yu to be the same as the 種 yu, which ancient authors describe as a marsh or water-plant like silk floss; long leaves which are eaten by horses; stem with joints. It has a fetid smell. Williams, Dictionary, 1113, thinks that it may be a Potamogeton.

The Shuo wen keeps the two characters yu distinct. According to this dictionary 菌 is another term for 漂 (to strain spirits) and 種 (a plant growing by the edge of the water).

The stinking plant yu is mentioned in the Tso chuan, 141, [B.C. 655], in an oracular passage, saying:—there is a fragrant herb and a noisome one, and ten years hence the noisomeness will continue (一薦一薦十年尚猶有臭).

Siebold, Icon. jap., ined., VI, 種 Phænoides japonica (Clerodendron). [See also Phon zo, XX, 13.]

E., 108, family 種. The figure seems to indicate a Potamogeton. Jap., 627, Clerodendron divaricatum, S. & Z., may caution us not to accept Japanese identifications without guarantee from Chinese sources.

86.—菌 Lu; 蔓 Ts'u.

Kuo P'o:—A plant used for making shoes.

87.—柱夫 Chu fu; 搖車 Yao ch'e.

Kuo P'o:—A trailing plant with small leaves, violet flowers, edible. The people now call it 翻搖車 K'siao yao ch'e.

V. infra, 448, Vicia hirsuta.
EXPLANATION OF NAMES OF HERBACEOUS PLANTS.

E., 72, family 麥穀, with figure of a Vicia.

The synonym 種穀, from the Shi king [v. infra, 448]. That this term is not mentioned in the Rh ya, while two others are, is a proof that the present text of the Shi king is not what it was about 300 B.C. There are many more such cases, all specially inexplicable by the commentators.

88.—出陸 Ch'u sui; 蕨菜 Ku shu.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 土菌 T'u kan (a mushroom) and is produced within the 蘇草 Ku tsao [Hydropyrum latifolium. V. infra, 350]. The people of Kiang tung eat it. It is sweet and mucilaginous.

The corresponding figure of the Rh ya represents a mushroom.

E., 40, family 蘑, makes the two terms simply synonyms. It is possible that the young sprouts of Hydropyrum were considered to have the quality of mushrooms. Whether a peculiar mushroom grows among H's should be ascertained from a professional botanist.

The two terms are from the Rh ya. 蘑 is mentioned in the Li ki. P., 19, 17; 23, 15. 蘑子 is mentioned E., 52, among the 蘑 or mushrooms.

89.—新花 K'in (k'i) ch'i; 藤燕 Mi wu.

Kuo P'o:—This is a fragrant herb with small leaves, resembling the 薰 Wei. HUAI NAN-TSZ [2nd century B.C.] says that it resembles the 蛇牀 She ch'uang [an umbelliferous plant, Selinum or Cnidium]. The mi wu is mentioned in the Shan hai king.

HING PING:—Another name is 肖鬚苗 Kung k'uing miao. In the Pen ts'ao it is also called 薰燕 Wei wu and 江離 Kiang li. T'AO Hung-king says that the plant resembles the she ch'uang [v. supra].

The fragrant plant in question is mentioned in the Li sao. [v. infra, 411, 412, ch'i and kiang li.]

E., 143, family 藤燕. Both disyllables are from the Rh ya.

The figure represents an Umbelliferous plant, but without flower or fruit.
90.—茨 Tsi li; 草 Tsi li.

Kuo P'o:—This plant creeps on the ground. It has small leaves. The fruit is provided with three prickly horns.

This is the *Tribulus terrestris*, L., and this plant may also be recognised in the corresponding drawing of the *Rh ya*.

[Comp. infra, 427].

E., 141, family 草, with a good figure of *Tribulus terr.*.

C., 52. S., I., 38. P., XVI, 87. Sm., 221.

91.—葛蔓 Ki ju (na); 窃衣 Ts'ie i [stealing clothes].

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 草 Kin [*Eranthe stolonifera*, an umbelliferous plant] and is edible. Seeds hairy, as large as a wheat-grain, two together, opposite; they stick to people's clothes.

Hing Ping:—Popular name of the plant 鬼麦 Kui mai (devil's wheat). Not mentioned in the *Pen ts'ao kang mu*.

Jap., 539, *Cancalis jap.*, Houtt., 窃衣 (=Torilis Anthriscus, Gmel., Index Fl. S., 337).

92.—髦 Mao; 頭殼 Tien ki.

Kuo P'o:—A creeping plant with small leaves and prickles. Another name is 商蔔 Shang ki. The Kuang ya calls it 女木 Nü mu.

Not found in the *Pen ts'ao kang mu*.

E., 173, family 天門冬, *Asparagus*. Several wild species grow in China.

The two names, infra, 108, are synonyms.

93.—葛 Kuan; 花蘭 Huan lan.

Kuo P'o:—A creeping plant, the stalks of which, when broken, exude a milky juice; edible.

[V. infra, 468, *Metaplexis Stauntonii*].

E., 141, family 花蘭, with a good figure.

In this case kuan, the term of the *Rh ya*, stands first, and huan luan, of the *Shi king*, below it.
94.—薑 T'iu; 薑 Ch'en jian.

Kuo P'o:—It is found in the mountains. The leaves resemble those of the 茴 Kiu (Allium odorum). Another name is 提母 T'i mu.

Hing Ping:—It is a medicinal plant, also called 知母 Chi mu. The Pen ts'ao gives more than ten synonyms. T'ao Hung-king says it resembles the 昌蒲 Ch'ang p'u (Acorus), and is flexible.

P., XIIa, 39, chi mu, and Ch., VII, 41, rough drawing. Root used in medicine. Tatarinov, Catal. med. sin., 16, chi mu, Radix Anemarrhena asphodeloides. Hanbury, Scient. Papers, 259, describes and figures the rhizome of this plant beset with rufous hairs. This liliaceous plant is common in the Peking mountains. It has long linear lanceolate radical leaves. The scape is 3-4 feet high with a long terminal spike of small brownish violet flowers.

So moku, II, 14, and Phon zo, V, 20, 21. 知母 Anemarrhena asphodeloides, Rge.

E., 129, family 知母. The three very different figures are copies from S., II, 27. The first figure is probably intended for the same as the first in E., 140, family 沙参 (Adenophora), where 知母 is one of the synonyms. One of the figures may mean Anemarrhena.

Jap., 153. C., 136. Sm., 17; but Sm., 57, Chelidonium majus. Where in China is Ch. called so?

95.—薑 Yu; 薑 Si.

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 湿薑 Tse si.

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao calls it 湿薑 Tse sie, also 水薑 Shui sie. Other names 及薑 Ki sie, 芒芋 Mang yu, 鳥薑 Ku sie. T'ao Hung-king says:—its leaves are narrow and long; it grows in shallow water.

P., XIX, 1, tse sie, a water-plant. Tse sie is the vulgar name of our common Alisma plantago, which in Northern China is frequently seen in water-ditches. The roots produce
large tubers, which are used in medicine. Good drawings of the plant, sub. 深瀉, are given in the Kiu huang, XLVII, 5, in Ch., XVIII, 1, and in the Japanese So moku, VII, 35.

E., 140, family 深瀉. One of the four figures is a good drawing of Alisma pl.

S., I, 21, has three figures. The figure to P., 19, 1, agrees with one in E., 140, named tse sic of 豫州.

C., 1354. Sm., 7.

96.—菌 Kan; 鹿藿 Lu ho; 其實荊; its fruit is called nin (ch'ou).

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 鹿豆 Lu tou (deer's bean). The leaves resemble those of the 大豆 Ta tou (Soja hispida). A climbing plant. Fragrant, yellow root.

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao says that it has a bitter taste.

P., XXVII, 27, 鹿藿 Lu ho, also 蓮豆 Lao tou, a climbing leguminous plant, wild-growing, used as a vegetable. The small black seeds, which resemble pepper, are edible. The Kiu huang, LIII, 15, and Ch., III, 45, figure the lu ho with trifoliate leaves.

So moku, XIII, 33, 鹿藿 Rhychosia volubilis, Lonr. The Phon zo, I, 2, 3, applies this Chinese name both to Rhychosia and to Glycine ussuriensis, Rgl.

Loureiro, Flora cochin, 562, says, regarding Rhychosia volubis:—caulis volubilis, folia ternata, semina nigra nitida. Habitat inculta prope Cantonem. Nomen sinicum Chio tau (perhaps 菜豆).

E., 37, 9, family 荨. The figure, like that in P., 27, is not with trifoliate leaves.

E., 131, family 荨, the term lu ho is synonymous with ko (Pachyrhizus [v. infra, 390]).

97.—蒿 Hao; 候莎 Hou sa; 其實荊; its fruit is called ti.

Kuo P'o:—The hao is mentioned in the Hia Siao cheng (Calendar of the Hia Dynasty). It is also called 蒿蔴 So sui.

Hing Ping:—The Kuang ya calls it so sui and 地毛 Ti mao.
The above-quoted passage in the Hia Calendar is 正月
Douglas translates it:—in the first month fruits
the Cyperus. The Shuo wen explains the character 涩 by
鑑候.

P., XIVb, 58, 涩草 So ts'ao or 香附子 Hiang fu tsz' (fragrant tuber).

As synonyms are given the names in Rh ya 73 and 97.
But the author of the Pen ts'ao kung mu, and before him
other Chinese authors, confound two distinct cyperaceous
plants. Rh ya 73 is the so ts'ao a Scirpus or Cyperus, the
fibres of which, in ancient times, were made into rain cloaks
and hats [see also infra, 457], but the plant hao [97] seems
to denote the hiang fu tsz', which is the Cyperus rotundus, L.
Its fragrant tubers are used in medicine.

Loureiro, Flora cochin., 58, Cyperus rotundus, L., since
liam phu fu. Hoffm. & Sch., 192, 193, refer the name
香附子 only to Cyperus rotundus, and 涩 to C. Iria. But
the Phon zo, IX, 35, applies both these Chinese names to
Cyperus rotundus, as does also Ch., XXV, 35. The figure in
this latter work represents a sedge with oblong tubers.

E., 107, family 涩, the figure is bad, a Cyperus probably
intended [v. supra, 73]. Jap., 731, 涩草科 Cyperaceae.

C., 412. A., XV, 181. [Sm., 81, C. esculentus], under the
name Hiang fu. Jap., 740, Cyperus rotundus, L., 香附子.

98.—莞 Kuan (juan); 荷葉 Fu li; 其上葉. The upper
part of the plant is called li. [See also 4, where the same
name (li) is applied to an Allium.]

Kuo P'o:—Nowadays the people of 西方 Si fang
(Western China) call the 濤 P'u (cat's-tail, Typha, v.
infra, 375) 官滿 Kuan p'u, and its head li. In Kiang tung
the same plant is called fu li, and by li they understand the
inner part of the stem, of which mats are woven.

6 隨 Fu properly denotes the tuberous root of Aconitum.
Hing Ping:—某氏 states that jin li is another name for the 白蒲 pai p'iu (white rush). In 楚 Chu (Hu kuang) it is called 蒲 kuan p'iu and its head is li. Cheng Huan, in commenting upon the Shi king, says:—the 蒲 kuan is a water plant, it grows thickly crowded together, has a round stem. It resembles the 小蒲.

P., XIV, 14, gives kuan as a synonym for 白芷 pai chi. But this is evidently a mistake, for pai chi is an umbelliferous plant [c. infra, 410], whilst kuan is a rush [c. infra, 455].

E., 68, family 蒲, with six figures, apparently all Acorus, except the last, which is a Typha. 31 names are given; p'iu and han are from the Shi king.

P., XIX, 13, with the names 香蒲 and 黄蒲.

C., 420, Typha japonica, Miq. = Jap., 2253.

B., T. augustifolia, L., Sui., 223, T. Bungeana, Tatar.

99.—荷 Ho; 荷渠 Fu ku. The Lotus, Nelumbium speciosum.

其莖 its stem is called kia.

其葉 its leaf is hia.

其本著 its lower part is mi,

Kuo Po:—Another name for the ho plant is 荷花 fu yung. In Kiang tung the name ho is usual. Regarding the character 葉 mi, Kuo Po says that it is the white rhizome (白藕) of the plant which is amongst the mud.

E., 93, family 藤, with a good figure.

C., 721-729. Pr., 136, 137. Sui., 139. S., XI, 15.

Pr., 219, gives 花蓉, for Crossostephium artemisioides, Less., (a Composite). These two characters are also used for Hibiscus mutabilis, L., in Canton Province, or in South China according to W.D., 144. E., 93, quotes it as a synonym for Nelumbium, from the 古今注.

100.—其華花著 its flower is han tan.

其實蓮 its fruit is lien.

Kuo Po:—Lien means the 房 Faug, or receptacle.
EXPLANATION OF NAMES OF HERBACEOUS PLANTS.

101.—其根藷. Its root is ou.

其中的. The seed is called ti. [Comp. also 191.]

的中意. The centre of the ti is called i.

Kuo Po explains that by ti the seeds inside the lien, or receptacle, are meant, and that i is the bitter heart (of the seed), the cotyledons.

Hsing Ping.—Li Sun says that all the above terms (99-101) refer to the 花蕓 fu k'ü and its stem, leaves, flowers, fruit and root. The people in Kiang tung call the flowers of the ho plant 花蕓 fu yung. In Northern China the root (ou) is called ho, and the term ho is also applied to the lien or receptacle. In Shu (Sz ch'unan) they call the root 蕨 kia.

The Rh ya gives under the above names two quite exact drawings of Nelumbinum speciosum. It is also figured in Kiu huang, LVIII, 22, Ch., XXXII, 9, and So moku, X, 9, 10. Description in P., XXXIII, 16. [V. also infra 395.]

102.—紅 Hung; 龍古 Lung ku: 其大者為 that of large size is called k'ui.

Kuo Po.—The common name is 紅草 hung ts'ao, also 龍鼓 lung ku.

Hsing Ping.—She Jen gives the names hung and 龍古 lung ku. In the Shi king it is termed 游龍 yu lung (and 藤 liao).

V. infra, 426, Polygonum orientale.

The drawing in the Rh ya agrees.

E., 58, family 藤, with two figures, of which one is not a Polygon.

S., III, 38. P., 16, 79, with a good figure.

103.—蔓 Ts'o; 醫寶 the fruit of the tsi.

Kuo Po explains:—the seeds of the tsi plant.

Hsing Ping.—The Pen ts'ao says the tsi is of a sweet taste. A soup can be made by boiling the leaves. Mentioned in the Shi king.

V. infra, 367, Capsella bursa pastoris.
104.—纖 Fen; 果實 fruit of the i (si) plant.

果 I (si) is the same as 麻 ma (hemp).

Kuo P'o quotes the Li ki 草木之有纖, the female hemp bears the fen. But this passage is, as Hing Ping corrects, from the Li.

V. infra, 388, Cannabis sativa, L.

E., 38, family 麻, sub-family 胡麻. The figure represents Sesamum indicum, L. Other sub-families [v. 140 and 388].

105.—須 Su; 蔬菜 Sun wu.

Kuo P'o:—The plant (root) resembles a 羊蹄 yang ti (sheep's hoof). It (the leaves) can be eaten; is of a sour taste.

Hing Ping:—According to Mao, this is the same as the 藜 feng of the Shi king [v. infra, 361]. Sun Yen says that the su feng tsung [Rh ya, 83] is also the same. Some commentators identify the feng with the 藜菁 man tsing, which is a Rape.

P., XIX, 7, identifies the su or sun wu with the 酸模 suan mo, which is a Sorrel, Rumex. [V. infra, 441.]

E., 160, family 酸模, with figure of Rumex.

One synonym is Mountain Rhubarb, 山大黃.

E., 69, family 藜菁, has figures of four different plants. The same terms from the Rh ya are enumerated here as in E., 160.

106.—非 Fei; 蔬菜 Si ts'ai.

Kuo P'o:—The fei plant grows in low, damp places. It resembles the 蕨菁 wu tsing (rape) but has violet flowers. It is edible.

Hing Ping:—In another place (50) the Rh ya states that fei is the same as 菜 wu. But this is a different plant mentioned in the Shi king.

V. infra, 363, Radish?

E., 104, family 非 [v. supra, 50].

蕓菁 is a synonym of 蕨菁 according to E., 69.

107.—黃 K'ei; 赤莧 Chi hien (red Blitum).

Kuo P'o:—This is a variety of the hien (Blitum) with a red stem.
Hing Ping: 草菜 Hien ts'ai, a vegetable, with a red stem. According to P., XXVII, 9, 草 hien is a general name for several species of Amaranthus. At Peking it is applied to Amaranthus Blitum, L. Figured under hien in Kiu huang, LVIII, 25, and Ch., III, 9.

Sieb. Plant. acon. japon., 124, 草 Amarantus oleraceus, L., (a) caule foliisque viridibus, (b) caule foliisque purpurascentibus.

Phon zo, XLVIII, 17-19, 草 Amarantus mangostanus, L., and same Chinese name applied to Eucolus viridis, Moq. (Amarantus Blitum in THBG. Flora japon., 57). Ibidem, 20, 赤草 A. melancholicus, L., also A. candidus, L., and A. tricolor, L., all with purplish foliage.

So moku, XX, 22, 草 Amarantus melancholicus. Ibidem, 23, 野草 Eucolus viridis.

E., 61, family 草. Two figures, one representing an Amaranthus, the other Portulacca oleracea, L. S., X. 4. L., XV, 106, 168, 紅草 A. tricolor, L.; 白草 A. polygamus, L. W. D., Chenopodium (Spinacia). Sm., 59, Ch. rubrum.

108.—膳席 Ts'iang mei (mi); 食冬 men tung.

Kuo Po:—According to the Pen ts'ao this is the 門冬 men tung or 滿冬 man tung.

Hing Ping quotes the Shan hai king. Now the Pen ts'ao writes the name 天門冬 t'ien men tung, also 頭勒 tien le, 廢門冬 mai men tung. In 秦 T'sin (Eastern Kansu and Shensi) it is called 羊韭 yang kiu (sheep's Allium), in 齊 T'si (Northern Shantung) 爱韭 ai kiu, in 楚 Ch'u (Hukwang) it is 馬韭 ma kiu (horse's Allium), in 越 Yne (Chekiang) it is 羊著 yang shi. Other names are 禹蔘 yu kia and 禹餘糧 yu yu liang.

The commentators of the Rh ya here confound under the above names two plants which are kept apart in the Pen ts'ao kang mu.

天門冬 T'ien men tung, P., XVIII, a, 47. The plant cultivated at Peking under this name is Asparagus lucidus.
Lin-l. Ch., XXII, 9, figures s.n. a plant with tuberous roots, linear leaves (Asparagus). See also Kiu huang, LI, 4.

Hanbury, Science Papers, 257, describes the tubers of the Chinese tien men tung, received from Shanghai, supposing that they belong to Loureiro's Melanthium cochinichinense, Flor. Cochin, 268, tien menen tum. See Bentham's note on this plant in Flora Hongk., 371, sub. Asparagus lucidus.

Henry, Chinese Names of Plants, 463, T'ien men tung in Hupeh is Asparagus lucidus.

So moku, VII, 7, 天門冬 Asparagus lucidus, Lindl.

The other Men tung is the 麥門冬 Mai men tung. This plant, much cultivated at Peking, is the Ophiopogon spicatus, Gawl. It is described P., XVI, 16; good drawings of the plant are found in the Kiu huang, LI, 6, and Ch., XI, 10.

Hanbury, Science Papers, 256, figures the tubers of the Mai men tung. Amien exot., 823, 門冬 Ophiopogon japonicus, Gawl., with figure. So moku, VI, 46, 小葉麥門冬 (mai men tung with small leaves) is Oph. japonicus, and, 45, 大葉麥門冬 (the large leaves) is Oph. spicatus.

It cannot be decided whether the men tung in the Rh ya is intended for Asparagus or Ophiopogon. The men tung is repeatedly noticed in the Shan hai king.

E., 173, family 天門冬, with seven figures, of which five may represent species of Asparagus, the first being a good figure of A. lucidus. [V. supra, 92.]

S., I, 5, represents two kinds. Pr., 206. A., XV, 179.

C., 1301, Asp. filicius, Ham.; 1302, also A. lucidus.

E., 174, family 麥門冬, with three figures, apparently of Ophiopogon.

S., I, 15. A., XV, 179, according to Loureiro, Aneilema medica, R. Br.

Sua., 17, Aneilema medica; 162, Ophiopog. jap.; 194, Scorzonera.

Both names of the Rh ya are heading E., 173 and E. 174.

109.—篇荷止. Unknown to the Chinese commentators.
EXPLANATION OF NAMES OF HERBACEOUS PLANTS.

110.—榮 Lo; 賢菜 Kuan Chung.

Kuo P'o:—Leaves round and pointed. Stem black, covered with hairs. It covers the ground; does not die in winter. Another name is 賢菜 Kuan k'ü. The Kuang ya calls it 賢菜 kuan ts'e.

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao gives the names 百頭 Po t'ou, 虎卷 Hu kün, 董荷 [c. 109], 伯蔘 Po ping, 藥藻 Yo ts'ao, 氏頭 Chi t'ou (owl's head). T'ao Hung-king says, the leaves of this plant resemble those of the 大蕨 tu k'üe (a fern), are covered with hairs, and resemble the head of an owl [probably the young unexpanded leaves].

Kuan chung is a fern. P., XII b, 18. Root said to be poisonous. Ch., VIII, 16, represents under kuan chung, a fern with pinnate fronds.

Phon zo, VI, 3, 4, 賢菜, a fern, according to Franchet, Lomaria japonica, Kunze. According to Fauvel [A Naturalist in the Far East, 11] the above Chinese name is applied in Shantung to Aspidium falcatum, Hance. Henry, Chinese Names of Plants, 199, kuan chung in Hupei a large fern, the rhizome of which is used as a drug, Woodwardia radicans, Sw. Ibidem, 200, 毛賈菜 Mao kuan chung (hairy kuan chung) Onoclea orientalis, Hook., and Nephrodium filix mas, Rich., our common male fern.

E., 133, family 賢菜. The figure is a copy of S., IV, 21, and nearer to Aspidium falcatum than to a Woodwardia. The figure in P., XII, differs, being bipinnate.

Jap., 253, gives the name for Asp. falcatum, Sw.

C., 647, Woodwardia and perhaps other large Ferns.

111.—若 Kän; 牛藻 Xin ts'ao.

Kuo P'o:—It resembles the 藻 T'sao [v. infra, 401]. The people in Kiang tung call it 馬藻 Ma ts'ao.

V. infra, 401, Potamogeton.

E., 66, family 藻, with two figures, one may be intended for a Potamogeton or a Najas.
Sm., 129, *Laminaria* includes one of the names given here as a synonym. It is possible that some Chinese apply the terms to sea-weeds [v. infra, 197] and other water-plants.

Jap., 1742, *Potamogeton oxyphyllus*, Miq., 馬尾. [Comp, supra, 85.]

112.—蕪菜 *Chu shang*; 馬尾 *Ma wei* (horse's tail).

Kuo P'o:—The *Kuang ya* has 馬尾 *Ma wei* or 蕨陸 *Shang lu*. The *Pen tsao* writes 蕨菜 *Shang*. The same name is in use in Kuan si (Southern Shensi). In Kiang tung the people call it 當陸 *Tang lu*.

Hing Ping:—The *Pen ts'ao* gives also the names 蕨根 *Shang ken*, 夜呼 *Ye hu*, 白昌 *Pai ch'ang*.

In P., XVIIa, 8, the *Shang lu* is described as a plant with large, thick leaves, resembling the 牛舌 *Niu she* (*Rumex*); the root resembles that of the radish. There are two sorts, one with white flowers and a white root, the other with purple flowers and purple root. The latter is said to be injurious to men. The plant is much cultivated in gardens. Roots and leaves are cooked and eaten. The root is also used in medicine.

At Peking *Shang lu* is *Phytolacca acinosa*, Roxbg., which is also found in India. According to ROXBURGH, in India the leaves are eaten after boiling, as is the case with *Ph. decandra*, the Pokeweed of N. America, the root of which is emetic and cathartic.

Ch., XXIV, 3, *Shang lu*, good drawing of *Phytolacca*. It is represented also in *Kiu huang LI*, 5.

Amæn. exot., 828, 蕨陸 *sjooriku*, vulgo jamma gobo. (*Cumicone*), *Planta sylvestris radice rapacea eduli*... folio Lapathi, etc. This is *Ph. acinosa*. So moku, VII, 90, same Chinese name, *Ph. acinosa*.

E., 131, family 蕨陸, with a good figure of *Phytolacca*.

The term *lu* [v. I king].

S., IV, 25, with two bad figures. C., 1111. Sm., 171.
EXPLANATION OF NAMES OF HERBACEOUS PLANTS.

113.—萍 P'ing; 藓 P'ing.

Kuo P'o:—This is a water-plant, called also 浮萍 fou p'ing (floating p'ing). In Kiang tung it is called 漂萍 p'iao.

The drawing of the Rh ya represents duck weed, Lemna. [V. infra, 400.]

E., 67, family 藻. The figure, a copy of S., III, 9, is not of Lemna, but of Monochoria Korsakowii, Regl. B., gives 藻藻 for Lemna, Azolla. [Jap., 133, Azolla pinnata, R. Br. 漂江紅.]

114.—其大者 藻 A larger kind (of the p'ing. This is Marsilea. [V. infra, 400.]

E., 67, family 藻, with a good figure of Marsilea.

Jap., 1499, gives M. quadrifolia, L., with this Chinese name.

115.—菴 Hli; 免菴 T'u k'ui (hare's mallow).

Kuo P'o:—The plant resembles the k'ui (mallow) but it is smaller. In shape the leaves resemble the leaves of the 藜 li (Chenopodium). The plant is covered with hairs. It can be eaten, is mucilaginous.

P., XVI, 28, t'u k'ui. Vagne, confused description. The corresponding drawing Ch., III, 7, seems to refer to a Mallow.

Hoffm. & Schultes, 42, 免菴 Anemone altaica, Fish. The same Chinese name is applied in the Phon zo, XVII, 19, to Anemone flaccida, Schm., in the So moku, X, 35, to Eranthis keiskii, Franchet, (Ranunculaceae).

E., 85, family 菟 [v. supra, 76]. The figure of t'u k'ui is not of a mallow.

P., XVI, 28, figure indicates a Malva.

Jap., 882, Eranthis pinnatifida, Max.

116.—芹 K'in; 楚菴 Ch'u k'ui (mallow of Ch'u [Hukuang]).

Kuo P'o:—Commonly called 芹菜 K'in ts'ai. It is an aquatic vegetable.

Hing Ping:—The Pen ts'ao calls it 水芹 Shui k'in or 水菴 Shui ying. T'ao Hung-king states that in the second or third month the young leaves are eaten, after cooking, or salted. Another kind, which is called 浮芹 cha k'in can be eaten raw.
Others say that there are two sorts of *k'in*, the 薤蔘 *Ti k'in*, of which the white root is used, and the 赤蔘 *Chi k'in* (red *k'in*), of which the stems and leaves are employed for pickles or salted.

*V. infra*, 370, *Oenanthe stolonifera*.

*E.*, 65, family 芹. *H.* 67. *Sm.*, 20, *Apium graveolens*; 57, Celery, parsley and watercresses.

117.—薔 *Tu'i*; 牛薔 *Nin tu'i*.

*Kuo P'o*—In Kiang tung its common name is *nin tu'i*. The plant grows more than a foot high; it has a square stem, long pointed leaves, ears with violet bluish flowers. The people make an infusion of the plant and drink it.

*Hing Ping*—*Cheng Huan* says that this is the 蕺 *Ch'u* of the *Shi king*. [*V. infra*, 440, *Rumex*.]

*E.*, 64, family 蓼, figure leaves of *Rumex*.

118.—薔 *Su*; 牛脣 *Niu shan* (oxlip).

*Kuo P'o*—The *su* is mentioned in the *Shi king*. *Mao* says that it is the same as the 水薔 *Shui si* [p. 95, *Alisma plantago*]. It resembles the 薔 *Sn tuan*. The plant has joints one inch apart.

The *su tuan* is mentioned in *P.*, XV, 45, and the name is written there 紙斷. At Peking this name is applied to *Dipsacus japonicus*, Miq. The drawing in *Ch.*, XI, 33, *su tuan*, seems to represent a *Dipsacus*. *Henry*, *Chinese Names of Plants*, 164, *su tuan* in Hupei is *Dipsacus asper*, Wall. The root of the *su tuan*, as the name indicates, is said to have the power of joining together broken bones. Comp. regarding the medicinal virtues of this plant *Mém. conc. les Chinois*, IX, 166.

In Japan the Chinese name 紙断 is applied to *Lamium album*, L. See *So moku* XI, 11.

We are left in doubt what the *su*, or oxlip plant, was. [*V. infra* 437.]

*E.*, 133, family 紙断, with two figures, one *Dipsacus*, the other a *Lamium*, copied from *S.*, I, 43. *C.*, 474, *Dip. asper*, Wall., or *Lamium album*, L., Var. barbatum. *Jap.*, 1226.
EXPLANATION OF NAMES OF HERBACEOUS PLANTS.

Sm., 64, *Cirsium lanceolatum* (probably a *Cnicus*).
The two terms are not mentioned in the *Rh ya*.

119. 一華 *Ping*; 藤蔘 *Lai shao*.
Kuo P'o:—It is now called 藤蔘 *Lai hao* (Artemisia). When young the leaves can be eaten. [V. infra, 372, *Artemisia.*]

E., 104, family 華, without figure.

120. 一連 *Lien*; 異類 *I kiao*.
Kuo P'o:—Another name is 運著 *Lien t'iao*. According to the *Pen ts'ao* it is also called 運草 *Lien ts'ao*.

Hing Ping:—Other names for this plant are 蘭華 *Lan hua*, 折枝 *Che ken* and 船 *Chi*. The commentator on the *T'ang Pen ts'ao* states that there are two kinds of this plant, the 大類 or great *kiao* and the 小類 or little *kiao*. The first has long, narrow leaves like the 水蘇 *Shui su* [v. 64], beautiful yellow flowers. The fruit is a capsule, resembling that of the 桂 *ch'un* (*Cedrela*). It grows in low, damp places. The little *kiao* grows on high mountains. It resembles the former, but the leaves and flowers are smaller.

P., XVI, 65, 運類 *Lien kiao*. Described as an herbaceous plant growing in damp places. Yellow flowers, fruit a capsule, resembling the fruit of *Cedrela*. Ch., XI, 61, s.n. bad drawing; 62, *lien kiao*, from Hunan and Yünman, seems to represent a *Hypericum*. Large yellow flowers. But the drug sold at Peking under the name of *lien kiao* is the capsules of a shrub, the *Forsythia suspensa*, Vahl. Hanbury received the same under the Chinese name *lien kiao* from Shanghai [Science Papers, 245].

Phon zo, XIX, 12, 13, 運類 *Hypericum ascyron*, L., and other species. So moku, XIV, 30, 32, 小運類 *H. erectum*, Thbg., and *H. japonicum*, Thbg. But in Japan likewise the name 運類 is applied also to *Forsythia suspensa*. Kwa wi, 109. Siebold, Icones, ined., V.
E., 131, family 连翘, with bad figure.
S., V., 4, with two figures, both bad, not like Hypericum.
Sm., 98, C., 719, and Jap., 965, Forsythia suspensa, Vahl.
Sm., 126, Justicia? Jap., 1119, 小连翘 Hypericum erectum,
Thbg.

121.—澤 Tse; 烏蔘 Wu sun.
Kuo P'o refers to 33, an obscure plant.

122.—傳 Fu; 横目 Huang mu.
Kuo P'o:—Other names 結縷 Kie lu, 鼓篩草 Ku cheng ts'ao.
Hing Ping:—A trailing plant.

E., 134, family 横目, without figure.

123.—蔓 Li; 蔓華 Man hua.
Kuo P'o:—Another name is 蔓華 Meng hua.

124.—菱 Ling; 藍菱 Kue mei.
Kuo P'o:—A water-plant, now called 菱 Ki.
Hing Ping:—The Ts'z't lin [third century] says:—The people of 楚 Ch'u (Hukuang) call it 藍菱 Ling. It is edible.
The 國語 Kua yu [fourth century B.C.] mentions the 菱 as an edible plant. Its common name is 蓮角 Ling kue.
This is the water caltrop, Trapa. [V. infra, 397.]
E., 99, family 菱, with figures of Trapa natans, L., in different stages. S., XI, 21. Sm., 221. H., 243-245.

125.—大菊 Tu ku (the great ku); 蓮麥 Ku mai.
Kuo P'o:—Other names 蓮句畫 Mai ku kiang; 蓮麥 Ku mai.
Hing Ping:—A medicinal plant. In the Kuang yu it is called 蓮菱 Ts'z't wei. Other names in the Peu ts'ao 蓮句麥 Ku ku mai, 大蘭 Ta lau. Tao Hung-king says:—Common by way-sides, red flowers.
The first name in Rh ya—Tu ku—properly means the great Chrysanthemum [comp. infra, 130].
P., XVI, 46, Ku mai or 石竹 Shi chu. This latter name, which first appears in the Ji hua pen ts'ao [tenth century]
denotes the pink, *Dianthus*. This plant is represented under the above names in the *Kiu hwaung*, XLVI, 8, and in *Ch.*, XI, 55. *Dianthus chinensis*, L., and *D. superbus*, L., are common plants in North China.

*So moku*, VIII, 20, 石竹 *Dianthus superbus*, L., 22, 石竹 *D. Scymnieri* (*D. chinensis*).

*E.*, 120, family 石竹, with a good figure of *Dianthus superbus*, L.

*C.*, 237. *Sui.*, 86, *Dianthus Fischeri* (= *chinensis*, L.).

*Jap.*, 787, *D. chin.*, 石竹, 790, *D. sup.* 露麦.

126.—牡鬚. Unknown to the Chinese commentators.

127.—薔 *Tsien*; 山莓 *Shan mei* (mountain berry).

*Kuo Pio:*—It is now called 木莓 *Mu mei* (tree berry). The fruit resembles that of the 薰莓 *piao* (*pao*) mei [*Rubus*, p. 190], but is larger. It can be eaten.

*P.*, XVIIa, ii, 懸鉤子 *Huan kon tsz*, described as a spiny shrub with red, sour, edible fruit. Identified with the *tsien* of *Rh ya*.

The plant represented under the above Chinese name in *Ch.*, XX, ii., is a *Rubus*. *Henry*, *Chinese Names of Plants*, 348, *huan kon tsz* in Hupei, *Rubus corchorifolius*, L. f.

*Amena. exot.*, 787, 藤 foo, item uoo, vulgo itzingo, *Rubus vulgaris fructu nigro*.

*SIEBOLD*, *Syn. pl. econ. jap*, 341, 懸鉤子 *Rubus palmatus*, Thbg. Same identification *Phon zo*, XXV, 17, 18.

*E.*, 114, family 懸鉤子, with a bad figure, probably *Rubus*, but not *corchorifolius*. *Jap.*, 1935, *R. incisus*, Thbg.

128.—薔 *Ye*; 苦薔 *Ku kin* (bitter kin).

*Kuo Pio:*—It is now called 薰葵 *Kin kuai*; leaves resemble those of the willow; small seeds. The plant is mucilaginous, edible.

*HING PING:*—A wild-growing vegetable, it resembles the 薰 *Ts'i* (*Houttuynia cordata*). It is mentioned in the *Li ki*
and *Shi king*. From the passages quoted it appears that *Hsing Ping* identifies the plant in question with the *kin* or violet [*v. infra*, 371]. But *P.*, XVIII, 50, refers the bitter *kin* of *Rh ya* to the 石龍荊 *Shi lung jin*, a poisonous plant, which according to the drawings *s.n.* *Ch.*, XXIV, 41, and *So moku*, X, 55, is *Ranunculus sceleratus*, L., a common plant in North China.

*E.*, 59, family 菊. The two figures show no resemblance to *Viola* nor to *Ranunculus*.

The second figure is a copy of *S.*, II, 33.

*Jap.*, 1857, has *Rou sceleratus*, with the name 石龍荊.

129.—薄 *T'ien*; 石衣 *Shi i* (stone clothes).

*Kuo P'o*—Same as 水苔 *Shui t'ui* (water moss), also called 石髮 *Shi fa* (stone hairs). The plant is eaten in Kiang tung. The leaves resemble the 頭 *Hiai* (*Allium*), but are larger. It grows at the bottom of the water.

*Hsing Ping*—This is the 海藻 *Hai tsao* (seaweed) of the *Pen ts'ao*.

In *P.*, XXI, i, the above names are referred to the 陸蘆 *Chi li*, called also 水絲 *Shui nien* (water filaments), a kind of water-moss growing on stones in ditches. See also *Ch.*, XVIII, 10.

At Peking *shui nien* is a *Conifera*.

*E.*, 74, family 諸苦, with a bad figure resembling sea-weed.

130.—薄 *Ku*; 治蕁 *Chi ts'iang*.

*Kuo P'o*—This is the 秋華菊 *Ts'in hua ku* or *Chrysanthemum*, which flowers in autumn.

*Hsing Ping* quotes the *Yue ling*. *Pen ts'ao* writes 菊華 *Ku hua* and 菊華 *Ts'e hua*. *T'ao Hung-king* says there are two kinds of this plant. One of them, properly so called, has a violet stem, is fragrant, and of a sweet taste. The leaves can be boiled into soup. The other kind has a green stem, is larger, of a bitter taste, not edible. It is also called 苦慧 *K'u i*.
The 菊 Kā is the *Chrysanthemum sinense*, Sub. See *P.*, XV, i, *Ch.*, XI, 1, 2, *So moku* XVII, 17, 18, 19.

Regarding the Kā in the Classics, *v. infra*, 404.

The corresponding drawing in the *Rh ya* is *Chrysanthemum*.

As to the Kēn ī it is noticed in *P.*, XV, 5. It is also called 野菊 Ye kū (wild *Chrysanthemum*). This latter name, in *So moku*, XVII, 22, is applied to *Pyrethrum setosum*, Maxim.

*E.*, 87, family 菊, with five figures.

*S.*, XII, 4; *H.*, 88; *C.*, 227; *Pr.*, 59.

*Jap.*, 1809, *Pyrethrum* (= *Chrysanthemum*) indicum, Cass., (L.)

野菊.

131.—唐 T'ang; 蒙 Meng; 女薬 Nü lo; 荻絲 T'ien szé (rabbit's silk). Comp. also 181.

This is the Dodder, *Cuscuta*, [*v. infra*, 450]. This plant is also intended in the corresponding drawing of the *Rh ya*.

*E.*, 169, family 荻絲. Figure is the same *S.*, I, 9, and *P.*, XVIII, 1.

*C.*, 1382-3, *Cuscuta chinensis*, Lam. *Sm.*, 87.

*E.*, 150, family 松薬, without figure, repeats all the names of *E.*, 169, but includes 松上寄生, a parasite on pine trees.

*Jap.*, 721, *Cuscuta japonica*, Chois.

132.—苗薬. Unknown to the Chinese commentators.

133.—荊 K'uai; 蓋荊 K'ue p'en.

Kuo P'io:—Same as the 覆蓋 Fu p'en. The fruit resembles the 薬 Mei, but is smaller. It is eaten.

Hing Ping:—Other names found in the *Pen ts'ao* are 蓮薬 P'eng lei, 陵薬 Ling lei, 險薬 Yin lei. The name of the fruit is 覆蓋子 Fu p'en tsé. An author of the T'ang period says that in a rich soil the plant produces large, sweet berries, but in a poor soil the fruit is small and sour.

Under the above names, given as synonyms, Hing Ping confounds several species of *Rubus*, kept distinct in the *Pen ts'ao kang mu*.

Kuo P'o:—It is now called 甘草 kan ts'ao (sweet herb); it is a creeping plant, leaves like those of the 荷 ho (*Nelumbium*), greenish yellow; the stem is red, has joints. Some say that the ling resembles the ti huang (*Rehmannia*).

Kuo P'o's account is absurd, but the ancient authors quoted in *P.*, XIIa, 1, give a correct description of the plant: leguminous with pinnate leaves, violet flowers, sweet root. *Ch.*, VII, 6, kan tsao, represents a *Glycyrrhiza* with echinate legumes. *Gl. globra* and *Gl. glandulifera*, which in Europe yield Liquorice, have both been recorded from North China by our botanists (*Index Flora sin.*, 168).

222.—木謂之華. The flower of a tree is hua.

而不實者謂之英. No seeds, is called ying.

Other Chinese authors, who are followed by Williams in his Dictionary, define the character siu by grain in seed, which then bends gracefully. Williams translates the character ying by a flower whose fruit is not yet formed.

Kuo P'o:—This is the 白樫 Pai kia; it resembles the 白楊 Pai yung (white poplar).
Hing Ping:—Its wood is moist.
In some editions of the Rh ya, and also in K.D., the first character is written 樫 tuan. This at Peking is a name for the Lime tree, Tilia, not mentioned in P. [Comp. also above 6.]
The 樫 kia tree is likewise not described in P., but a rough figure of it, which is not sufficient for its recognition, is given in the Kiu huang, LIV, 36, and reproduced in

Ch., XXXIV, 21. The kia tree is mentioned by T'ao Hung-king [5th century] who in his note regarding Ginseng quotes a Corean poem in praise of the Ginseng, saying that the kia tree and the Ginseng have mutual sympathy. T'ao adds that the kia is a tree resembling the 桐 (Paulownia), growing very high and giving an extensive shade. [See P., XIIa, 11, article 入参 Jen shen]. Reference is made to the kia tree in Grosier's La Chine, II, 289. It is described in K.K.F.P., LXXXI, 19, as a tree with large leaves collected together like a fan, the bark of which furnishes textile fibres fit for making fishing nets. 228.—枝 Pi; 竹 Shan (sha).

Kuo P'o.—The second character to be pronounced 枝 shan (sha). It denotes a tree which resembles the 枝 sung (Pinus) and grows in Kiangnan. Its wood is fit for shipbuilding, coffins, pillars; it is veined, does not decay.

P., XXXIV, 12, 枝 shan (sha). This character, another form of the shan in the Rh ya, is first met with in the Pie la [5th century]. The name is also written 沙木 sha mu. The ancient authors say that this is a large tree yielding excellent timber and resin; leaves like needles, sharp pointed, but flattened, evergreen. It is common in Middle China. Li Shih-chen states that there are several kinds of the shan tree, one of them introduced from Japan. One kind has a red wood and is very tough and resinous; the white shan is of a looser structure, and when dry becomes beautifully veined.

The shan tree of the ancient Chinese authors is without doubt the Cunninghamia sinensis, R. Brown, a common and very valuable coniferous tree of Middle and Southern China. Comp. Mr. Th. Sampson's interesting note regarding this tree in Notes and Queries on China and Japan, 1868, p. 52. But it seems that nowadays the name shan in China is applied also to Cryptomeria japonica, Don., and perhaps to other coniferous trees. Dr. Henry informs me that Cryptomeria japonica in Hupei, where it occurs wild, is one of the numerous 枝 sha trees of the Chinese.

In Japan, where Cunninghamia sinensis occurs only cultivated, the Chinese character 枝 denotes Cryptomeria japonica. See Phon za, LXXIX, 19, 20; Sieb. & Zucc., Flora japon., I, 43, tab. 124; Siebold, Syn. plant. econ. jap., 65.

In Ch., XXXIII, 58, the coniferous tree represented under 枝 is neither Cryptomeria nor Cunninghamia. A good drawing of the latter is found there, fol. 60, s.n., 沙木 sha mu.

I cannot say what the yen tree was. As to the nai, it is also written 核 [c. 244], this name is still in use and applied to a fruit which seems to be common in Middle China. Williams, Dict., 613, calls it a kind of bullace or large yellow plum, sour yet edible. The character nai is found in the Shuo wen and explained there: name of a fruit.

P., XXX, 15, has an account of the nai. It is mentioned in the Pie lo. Tao Hung-king says:—This fruit is found in Kiangnan, but it is more plentiful in the Northern States, where the fruit is dried for food. It is, however, not profitable to man. In P., XXXVI, 28, the ya or pai jui is identified with the 種核 jui ho. Li Shi-cheng says the character 植 of the Rh ya has the same pronunciation as 種, and has in later times been substituted for the first. Han Pao-sheng [10th century] describes the jui ho as a tree with leaves like those of the kou ki (Lycium), but smaller and narrower. White flowers. The stem is provided with numerous small spines. The fruits are produced on the stem; they are red and resemble the fruits called wu wei tsz (Schizandra). They ripen in the fifth or sixth month, are edible; the people gather and dry them. Another author says it is a small tree, from 5 to 7 feet high, with spines on the stem.

The drawings in the Kin huang, LV, 1, and in Ch., XXXVII, 35, 37, sub jui ho, seem to represent a Berberis. [See also Ch., XXXIII, 29.]

The drug sold at Peking under the name of 藤仁 jui jen (same as jui ho, for ho and jen both mean kernel) is the small stone of a fruit, probably a Prunus.

The 植 yu of the Shi king [v. 534], however, is an oak.

This name appears first, it seems, in the Si king tsa ki, compiled about the commencement of our era, and is applied to various wild pears and crab-apples with small, sour fruits.
